ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to draw using different tools (pencil, charcoal, ink, watercolor) and explored different techniques. I learned more about abstraction and the importance of noticing things.

I learned some basic skills and techniques for drawing, but on a more fundamental level I learned to look at the world differently, to experiment, to trust my instincts, to treat mistakes as opportunities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength is that the course was really flexible in the sense that you could draw whatever you wanted. I wish students were given more formal instruction on how to draw (realistic, shading, etc.), and I think we could have benefitted from more feedback.
Overall, this course was successful in encouraging me to draw more. However, I would have also enjoyed learning more fundamentals and learning about more artists.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning how to draw over Zoom wasn't the greatest, however, this is obviously out of the professor's control. I loved how we got to draw in person a few times, though.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to students if they're interested in art or drawing. This class was very chill, fun, and engaging.
I would recommend this course to any student, no matter their previous art/drawing experience, who wants to learn and grow as an artist and a thinker, and who isn't afraid to take risks.
Yes absolutely for both majors and non-majors. A very fun class, and the professor is incredibly encouraging of all of us.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were virtual seminars, in addition to occasional in-person class meetings (socially distanced).
All class was done virtually except for the 3 classes where we met, socially distanced, at the cemetery to do observational drawing.
Studio course translated into online class. There was lecture, presentations, as well as time for us to paint/draw separately and share among the class.
